title.narrative: Strengthening Capacities For Reducing Urban Vulnerability And Building Resilience In Southern Africa

description.narrative:
The programme ‘’Building Disaster Resilience to Natural Hazards in Sub-Saharan African Regions, Countries and Communities’’ was launched in 2015. It is implemented along five result areas by several partners, including the African Development Bank (AfDB), African Union Commission (AUC), the United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction (UNISDR) and the Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery (World Bank). Result Area 2, which is managed by GFDRR/World Bank, supports four Regional Economic Communities (RECs), including the Southern African Development Community (SADC), in Sub-Saharan Africa to ‘’have DRR coordination, planning and policy advisory capacities operational to support their respective member States and regional and sub-regional programmes’’. The programme will provide targeted support to RECs to strengthen their capacities for improved coordination, planning, policy advisory and knowledge dissemination to advance the regional disaster risk management (DRM) agenda and better support their member States in taking informed decisions towards building resilience to disasters.
To attain these objectives, the SADC Disaster Risk Reduction Strategic Plan focuses on capacity enhancement interventions for member States; assisting them to develop and implement the national DRR/DM strategies that are harmonized with the SADC Regional Indicative Strategic Development Plan (RISDP). The urban vulnerability and resilience agenda are linked to the global strategic guidance provided through the Sendai Framework and SDG11, and to facilitate innovation in DRR mainstreaming across a variety of development thematic areas, including urban planning.
The World Bank is supporting SADC in the implementation of the programme and has agreed to facilitate funding for a regional technical centre, which is highly competent in delivering technical assistance and capacity building, to design and implement DRM and urban resilience initiatives to support developing local, national and sub-regional capacities for reducing vulnerability and building the resilience of communities to natural and other hazards in the southern African region.
UN-Habitat has the technical expertise, know-how, and experience necessary for providing such a service, has already developed and tested the training and capacity building tools that will be implemented, and its urban specialization offers the comparative advantage to ensure an exceptional contribution. The Centre for Disaster Risk Management, Sustainability and Urban Resilience (DiMSUR) could act as the Regional Technical Centre with capacity for designing and implementing disaster risk management and urban resilience initiatives, since it has the experience (implementing CityRAP in 25 cities and 9 countries outreach) and the regional impact necessary to meet these needs.

mailing-address.narrative: UN-HABITAT P.O. Box 30030 GPO Nairobi 00100 Kenya
